results.title: Supply and demand
results.creator_credit: Ted Abenheim, Bruce Stubblefield and Greenhouse Films
results.brief_description: Basic introductory film on the concepts of supply and demand. Defines the law of supply and the law of demand, shows how the equilibrium point between these two laws determines prices, and provides examples of these laws in real life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ted Abenheim, Bruce Stubblefield and Greenhouse Films

results.title: Supervisory conferences
results.creator_credit: Art Babbitt, Edward L. Gershman, McGraw-Hill Text-Films and Academy Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Personnel Management”
Dramatised incidents in an industrial plant are used to show how conferences on the supervisory level lead to effective handling, training and utilisation of employees.

results.title: Supervising: developing co-operation
results.creator_credit: Caravel Films and United States. Dept. of the Navy
results.brief_description: Points out that the efficiency of an organisation depends on the morale of its personnel and then shows how office supervisors can help to foster a spirit of cooperation among civilian personnel. Right and wrong ways of supervision are demonstrated.

results.title: Supervising workers on the job
results.creator_credit: F.E. Brooker, Caravel Films and United States. Office of Education. Division of Visual Aids
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Problems in supervision”
Various kinds of poor supervision practices are shown, among them, nagging, snooping, etc. By dramatised incidents, the poor results of these methods are made apparent and the better ways indicated.

results.title: Supervising women workers
results.creator_credit: Herbert Kerkow and United States. Office of Education
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Problems in Supervision”.
A factory foreman discusses with the supervisor the “problem” of supervising women workers in his department. The fact is brought out that the same rules apply in supervising both men and women; but, “as women often have not had as much industrial experience as men, and in most cases have more home responsibilities than men, these factors must be taken into account”. Note that this film was made in 1944 and uses such terms as “breaking in” the female workers and “the eternal feminine”. Interesting from a historical point of view.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Herbert Kerkow and United States. Office of Education

results.title: Supervising for Service
results.creator_credit: Peter Quarry, Eve Ash and Seven Dimensions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Improving Service”.
Supervisors need to support frontline staff in serving customers by providing on-going training, being available when problems arise, motivating staff and improving poor individual service performance.

results.title: Supervise with care: three studies in worker supervision
results.brief_description: Describes three studies in worker supervision: expert workers who become annoyed when a supervisor takes notes of details without explanation; proper distribution of work among seniors and juniors brought about by discussion between supervisors and seniors; in placing junior workers, supervisors should consider their abilities.
